Matt and Juraj figured out the practicality of the CBC math (which is interesting in its own right), and Matt shepherded the issue and fix, and rounded-up when classifying it.https://twitter.com/colmmacc/status/1100420600063905792 …

1100424779922780160.text: When a CBC record comes in, it can be malformed in 2 ways: the padding can be wrong, or the signature (aka the MAC) can be wrong. Because the TLS design got the order of padding and MACs the wrong way around, it's important that implementations don't reveal which is wrong.

1100425239614304256.text: If implementations do, this is called a padding oracle attack, and if an attacker can get an implementation to encrypt the same data repeatedly, and also modify the encrypted traffic, and also observe the difference, eventually they would be able to decrypt the data. Sounds bad!
